The Energy Efficiency Investment Program is the first initiative in Pakistan 
to  integrate  energy  security  and  climate  change  into  a  common  strategic 
platform. It will establish a dynamic business environment for clean energy 
technology  and  finance  priority  projects.  It  constitutes  tangible  actions 
toward  a  sustainable  low-carbon  growth  path,  and  it  has  a  number  of 
important features:  
 
Mainstreaming Energy Efficiency. The Investment Program underpins a 
reform  strategy  that  will  mainstream  energy  efficiency  into  national 
planning and public investments, and is a critical component of Pakistan's 
climate change program. The Government of Pakistan (the Government) is 
adopting a holistic platform for strategic planning of the energy sector and 
climate  change.  The  Investment  Program  builds  on  ongoing  work  of  the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) to establish integrated energy planning. It 
backs  change  management  and  strengthens

Clean  Energy  Market  Transformation.  The  Investment  Program  will 
break down the financial barriers to clean energy investments, and finance 
deployment of clean technology that has been successfully demonstrated. 
It  will  strengthen  regulatory  and  institutional  frameworks,  establish  fiscal 
and financial incentives, and enforce standards and testing. 
 
Private Sector Engagement. The private sector will play a key role in the 
deployment of clean technology and energy services. It will also be a direct 
beneficiary  (on  the  supply  and  demand  sides).  Sustainable  business 
models  for  energy  efficiency  services  (i.e.,  energy  audits,  performance 
contracts) will be established and replicated. The Investment Program will 
increase industrial productivity and competitiveness by lowering operating 
costs.

The energy gap is now one of Pakistan’s most serious binding constraints 
to growth and jobs. It results from the rapid increase in demand and high 
wastage of energy, and is one of the main causes of the current economic 
crisis.  Pakistan’s  dependency  on  oil  imports  results  from  the  suboptimal 
energy supply mix that is a consequence of poor planning. The economy is 
susceptible to fuel price volatility. 
 
Pakistan  uses  15%  more  energy  than  India  and  25%  more  than  the 
Philippines (for each dollar of gross domestic product). Energy wastage is 
a  high  cost  to  the  economy,  businesses,  and  consumers;  its  reduction 
requires  major  and

In 2009, the power deficit reached 5,000 megawatts (MW), and natural gas 
supply  to  industries  was  cut  during  the  4  winter  months.  People  and 
businesses in many parts of Pakistan are experiencing power outages and 
rationing  lasting  more  than  12  hours  a  day.  Factory  closures  are  causing 
social unrest.  
 
Energy  efficiency  represents  the  least-cost  and  quickest  low-carbon 
solution  to  bridge  the  energy  gap.  It  cuts  the  high  dependence  on  oil 
imports  and  avoids  investment  in  expensive  and  inefficient  rental  power 
generation based on fossil fuels. It ultimately strengthens energy security, 
contributes  to  the  environment,  creates  jobs,  and  improves  industrial 
competitiveness.  Energy  efficiency  is  now  a  strategic  priority  for  the 
Government. 
 
Pakistan’s  total  energy  savings  potential,  through  the  application  of  clean 
and efficient technology, is estimated at 11.16 million tons of oil equivalent 
(493,304  terajoules  [TJ]),  or  18%  of  primary  energy  use  (FY2008).  This 
corresponds to a 51% reduction in net oil imports. In FY2008, the oil import 
bill  was  $12 billion.  Savings  in  electricity  and  gas  resulting  from  well 
thought  out  energy  efficiency  investments  correspond  to  additional 
generation capacity of about 6,770 MW.

Energy  efficiency  investments  can  be  most  effective  when  the  policy, 
regulatory, and pricing regime is right. Energy tariffs have historically been 
low in Pakistan. As such, customers have not had much of an incentive to 
invest  in  efficient  technology,  nor  shift  consumption  patterns.  While 
electricity production costs tripled from FY2003 to FY2007, tariffs were not 
adjusted  to  cover  this  increase.  Since  FY2007,  tariffs  increased  by  an 
average of 20% and will continue doing so until reaching cost-recovery by 
FY2011.  As  tariffs  increase,  so  does  awareness  of  energy  efficiency  and 
incentives to acquire new, less energy-consuming technology. 
 
The Government asked the Asian  Development Bank for  a flexible public 
sector  financing  mechanism  to  support  energy  efficiency  in  the  short  to 
medium  term.  A  multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  is  considered  the 
most  appropriate  modality  for  energy  efficiency  investments  in  Pakistan. 
The Government has fully met the preconditions for use of an MFF.

Strategic  Context.  Energy  security  is  the  primary  goal  under  Pakistan’s 
energy  strategy.  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  Pakistan  has 
energy efficiency as a core intervention area. The Investment Program is a 
continuation  of  a  10-year  policy  dialogue.  The  projected  investments  are 
consistent  and  closely  linked  to  ongoing  ADB  interventions—renewable 
energy,  power  generation  (mostly  private  sector  in  nature),  transmission, 
and distribution. These operations also fit with the latest negotiations with 
the  Government  on  policy  reforms  for  sustainable  and  financially  viable 
power sector.

efficiency  that  focuses  on  maximizing  energy  savings  by  rational  and 
efficient  use  in  all  energy-consuming  sectors.  An  integrated  institutional 
and  resource  allocation  structure  is  required  for  its  implementation.  The 
Investment Program projects will provide advisory and financial support to

the turnkey contracts will be utilized and incorporated into the procurement

All energy consumers in Pakistan will directly benefit from the Investment 
Program.  Large  economic,  social,  and  environmental  benefits  are 
expected  as  a  result  of  energy  savings  from  the  application  of  clean  and 
advanced technology and practice. For example:  
 
(i) 

601,671  tons  of  oil  equivalent  /25,191  TJ  (valued  at  $200  million) 
energy will be saved annually from reducing transformation losses in 
the power generation and gas transmission;  

(ii)  918,942  tons  of  oil  equivalent  /38,474  TJ  (valued  at  $330  million) 
energy will be saved annually from reducing gas, oil, and coal use in 
the domestic and industry sectors; and  

(iii)  GHG  emissions  will  be  cut  by  about  1  million  tons  carbon  dioxide 
equivalent annually from less fossil fuel use through clean technology 
and practice applications.  

 
Energy  efficiency  thus  will  reduce  public  sector  expenditures  on  energy 
and  improve  livelihoods  in  rural  and  urban  communities.  Implementation 
progress  and  achievements  will  be  monitored  against  the  performance 
targets  and  indicators  included  in  the  Investment  Program's  design  and 
monitoring framework. 
 
Financial  outlays  on  power  generation  projects  will  be  cut  and 
uneconomical  standby  capacity  required  to  cater  for  peak  loads  will  be 
minimized.  The  need  for  energy  subsidies  will  be  reduced.  Transmission 
and distribution system  expansion needs will be deferred, thereby saving 
public  funds  and  increasing  returns  on  all  energy  investments.  Energy 
efficiency  adds  more  supply  capacity.  The  potential  is  real  since 
investments are in technologies that are known, proven, bankable, and low 
risk in nature.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities  

13. 
The energy gap results from (i) weak sector planning and management, (ii) poor sector 
performance, (iii) increasing demand, and (iv) inefficient use of energy resources. The problem 
analysis  is  shown  in  Appendix  3.  Lack  of  investment  in  replacing  obsolete  technology  and 
infrastructure is a cause for inefficiencies. High energy losses and wastage throughout the value 
chain result in high energy intensity. Pakistan uses 15% more energy than India and 25% more 
than the Philippines for each dollar of GDP produced. Industrial production is impacted by high 
energy prices and low and unreliable supply. Production costs are high, making businesses less 
competitive. 
 
14. 
The Government is struggling to resolve the energy shortage crisis. Ad hoc measures, 
such  as  rental  power  generation  programs,  are  having  a  limited  impact.  Meanwhile,  public 
dissatisfaction  is  increasing  due  to  persistent  power  shortages  and  high  energy  prices.  The 
demand and supply gap can be bridged by (i) increasing supply through new capacity additions 
and  improved  sector  performance,  and  (ii)  increasing  supply  and  curbing  demand  through 
energy efficiency and demand-side management. The energy gap will continue to remain until 
both measures are effectively implemented.  
 
15. 
Increasing  supply  capacity  takes  time  and  is  expensive.  Commission  of  major  power 
generation and natural gas supply additions will begin in 2013. Pakistan is attempting to change 
its energy mix by exploring its hydropower and coal resources; however, these projects will take 
time. Reliance on thermal generation with imported fuel oil is expected to increase in the short 
term.  Energy  efficiency  thus  is  the  least-cost  and  most  climate-friendly  way  of  bridging  the 
energy  gap  and  securing  energy  provision.  Domestic  energy  prices  will  continue  to  increase 
with tariff rationalization and removal of subsidies. Energy efficiency reduces the energy bill for 
all energy customers.

35.

consumers’ time and money. Utility revenues will increase, resulting in improved service quality 
and financial performance. The cross-subsidy provided by utilities to low-income customers will 
be reduced.

A  country  assistance  program  evaluation  completed  in  May  2007  assessed  the 
development impact of ADB’s strategy and operations during 1985–2006. While the evaluation 
confirms  that  ADB’s  development  responsiveness  and  credibility  is  recognized  in  Pakistan, 
ADB’s  overall  program  and  sector  performance  was  rated  “partly  successful.”  The  evaluation

that  the  large  ADB  program  covered  too  many  sectors  and  interventions  with  too  few  staff, 
complex project designs hindered implementation, analytical work to support policy dialogue in

private sector. Operations in the energy sector were rated “successful.”17

The energy sector needs substantial investments. Consistent policy dialogue is required

influence  in  the  decisions  has  been  significant.  Power  unbundling  and  restructuring  has  been 
achieved  legally.  However,  power  utilities  lack  the  financial  autonomy  needed  to  make  sound 
commercial decisions and investment in system maintenance, operations, and expansion.  
 
ADB strategy has focused on supporting power transmission and distribution companies

Technical Aspects 

104.  The  Investment  Program  will  accelerate  the  deployment  of  clean  technologies  and 
initiate actions that will help realize energy savings potential in the country. Reduced electricity 
use in the industry, residential, and public sectors of 2,670 GWh per year amounts to 3.6% of the 
country’s  73,400  GWh  of  electricity  consumption.  The  corresponding  peak  load  reduction  of  
1,094 MW amounts to 8% of the country’s available generation capacity of 14,000 MW. Reduced 
transformation  and  supply  losses  of  601,671  toe  (26,595  TJ)  per  year  in  gas  transmission  and 
thermal power generation represent 1.3% of the country’s total oil and gas consumption in FY2008. 
Reduced  gas, oil, and coal  use in the  residential and industry sectors  amounting  to  918,942  toe 
(40,619 TJ) per year, represent savings of 2% of the country’s current total energy consumption.  
 
105.  CFL  Project.  Grid-connected  households  have  42  million  light  points  fitted  with 
incandescent  bulbs.  The  project  will  replace  10  million  incandescent  bulbs  in  2010  (phase  1) 
and 20 million in 2011 (phase 2). The maximum peak load from incandescent bulbs is estimated 
to be 3,166 MW in the country. Peak demand will be reduced by about 1,094 MW (at 66% peak 
coincidence),  resulting  in  savings  of  2,132  GWh/year  valued  at  $177  million.  Considering 
upstream  losses  and  reserve  margin  requirements,  the  CFL  project  is  therefore  capable  of 
avoiding  $1.84  billion  in  investments  for  1,600  MW  in  new  installed  peak  generation  capacity 
that would otherwise be required by 2011.

summer, and lasting approximately 5 hours in both cases. Household lighting represents 15% of 
this evening peak.

constant 2009 prices. Cost streams were used to determine the financial internal rate of return. 
The current generation tariff (February 2009) was used to calculate savings resulting from less 
electricity sold at below-cost rates to subsidized low-income customers, and the benefit gained 
by selling energy saved to retail customers above cost (in accordance with the overall customer 
sales  profile).  A  combined  preliminary  financial  internal  rate  of  return  estimate  of  97%  is 
recorded.  
 
D. 

Economic Analysis 

110.  The  projects  to  be  financed  under  the  Investment  Program  are  part  of  Pakistan’s 
integrated energy efficiency investment plan. They constitute a key component of the planned 
market  transformation and  deployment  of  energy-efficient technologies.  The economic  internal 
rate  of  return  (EIRR)  for  the  projects  was  determined  assuming  an  economic  discount  rate  of 
12%, exchange rate of PRs 80 = $1, and an oil price of $50 per barrel. Society’s willingness to 
pay was taken as the economic price of electricity, and is calculated at PRs 6.06 per kilowatt-
hour.  Natural  gas  is  priced  at  the  economic  price  of  imported  liquefied  natural  gas  for  the 
domestic  and  commercial  sectors,  and  at  fuel  oil  prices  for  the  industry  sector.  The  border 
prices  of  petroleum  products  in  the  country  are  linked  directly  to  international  crude  oil  prices. 
The  market  price  of  indigenous  and  imported  coal  is  adjusted  for  sales  tax  to  arrive  at  the 
economic  price  of  coal.  The  total  program  cost  is  estimated  at  $1,180  million.  After  valuing 
energy  benefits  at  their  economic  price,  the  aggregated  EIRR  for  the  six  components  is 
estimated to be 66%. A summary of the economic analysis is provided in Appendix 10.  
 
111.  The  EIRR  of  the  CFL  project  is  calculated  at  145%,  reflective  of  the  relatively  short 
period in which investment in a CFL can be recovered. 
 
112.  Sensitivity  of  project  economics  to  changes  in  key  variables  was  tested.  The  EIRR  is 
observed to be sensitive to the variables evaluated, but exceeds the economic hurdle rate for all 
sensitivities  tested,  including  the  multiple  downside  (combined)  scenario.  On  this  basis,  the 
projects appear to be economically viable.

Poverty and Social Assessment 

119.  The  energy  savings  will  contribute  to  increased  and  reliable  energy  supply  to  various 
sectors.  Poor  and  marginalized  populations  are  often  among  the  hardest  hit  by  energy 
shortages.  The  load-shedding  resorted  to  by  electrical  utilities  is  far  greater  in  rural  areas. 
Access to and affordability of modern energy services is also the lowest among the poor. These 
population segments are therefore expected to benefit from the energy savings, both in terms of 
associated costs as well as excess supplies made available to service their requirements.  
 
120.  The CFL project is designed to benefit households by providing them with CFLs at the 
cost  of  incandescent  bulb  replacement.  This  will  reduce  their  monthly  energy  bills.  Similar 
benefits  will  accrue  from  replacement  of  domestic  gas  appliances,  including  water  heaters, 
space heaters, and gas stoves.  
 
121.  The expected twofold increase in the use of CFLs by low-income (lifeline) customers will 
result  in  lower  monthly  electricity  bills  over  the  7.8-year  expected  lamp  lifetime.  For  end-user 
households,  as  much  as  $803  million  could  be  saved  in  electricity  use  over  the  life  of  the  
30 million CFLs. This translates to an average of PRs293 in annual electricity cost savings per 
incandescent bulb–CFL replacement for each household. The summary poverty reduction and 
social strategy is in Appendix 12.

I. 

Gender Aspects 

124.  The  Investment  Program  will  support  gender  mainstreaming  into  the  integrated  energy 
policy. The road map provides specific measures to allow the needs of both men and women to 
be considered in all planning and policy making. For the most part, policy makers in Pakistan do 
not  take  into  account  the  differences  between  men  and  women  relating  to  distribution  of,  and 
decision making over, energy services. As a result, policies generally do not recognize a gender 
bias  in  energy  services,  and  women’s  energy  needs  tend  to  be  marginalized  in  policy 
documents. 
 
125.  Policy  makers  need  to  become  aware  that  gender-neutral  energy  planning  misses 
important  issues  and  inadvertently  discriminates,  usually  against  women.  A  gender-sensitive 
energy  policy  would  recognize  that  women  and  men  have  different  energy  needs  due  to  their 
differing household roles, response to crises, and coping mechanisms; and would offer energy 
technologies and services that match those needs.  
 
126.  A gender-sensitive energy policy involves more than the creation of a gender-sensitive 
set of energy-related goals. The actual process of policy formulation and implementation needs 
to  be  gender-sensitive.  In  Pakistan,  the  energy  sector  is  male-dominated,  particularly  in  the 
professional  posts;  as  a  result,  issues  identified  and  solutions  offered  often  have  a  male  bias. 
Increased participation of women in the sector and improvement of their status relative to men 
can help to incorporate gender as an integral part of energy policies and practices, although it 
will  not  guarantee  the  adoption  of  gender-sensitive  policy  goals.  Engagement  of  women’s 
groups  may  be  important  for  incorporating  gender  issues  into  energy  policies.  A  shift  to  a 
demand-side  approach,  which  looks  at  energy  as  an  aspect  of  the  social  and  cultural  setting, 
(rather  than  the  traditional  supply-side  approach,  which  focuses  primarily  on  technological 
solutions) would contribute to more effectively addressing gender-related energy needs. 
 
J. 

Risks and Assumptions 

127.  Lack  of  progress  with  reforms,  a  deterioration  in  the  macroeconomic  situation, 
weaknesses in financial management, and institutional ineffectiveness are potential macro risk 
factors.  These  are  mitigated  by  a  commitment  of  the  present  Government  to  continue  with 
reforms, the economic stabilization program supported by the International Monetary Fund, and 
ongoing  and  planned  measures  to  improve  transparency  and  accountability  of  financial 
management systems.

128.  The key assumption made in designing the Investment Program is that the Government 
executes  the  energy  efficiency  sector  road  map,  successfully  combining  physical  and 
nonphysical investments. 
 
129.  Technical  risks  for  energy  efficiency  projects  are  assessed  as  relatively  low.  However, 
such projects can be successful only if the underlying incentives of the regulatory framework are 
in place and correct. For this, the political commitment and policy framework are critical. 
 
130.  The  Investment  Program  needs  good  institutions  and  strong  management  and 
governance.  Good  planning,  best  practice  concepts,  sound  project  management,  fiduciary 
oversight,  and  transparent  bidding  and  contract  management  processes  require  not  only 
experienced  personnel,  but  also  efficient  and  effective  systems,  procedures,  and  controls.  On 
the  institutional  front,  considerable  hope  is  placed  on  the  Planning  Commission's  ability  to 
manage the road map and the Investment Program. At the project level, utilities need to have 
adequate  capacity  to  manage  the  investments.  Project  management  capacity  of  utilities  is 
addressed  under  other  ADB  interventions,  and  the  Investment  Program  will  provide  required 
advisory services to prepare and implement specific projects. 
 
131.  The  Planning  Commission  will  be  responsible  for  implementing  the  energy-efficiency 
policy  and  associated  investment  projects.  A  dedicated  PMO  will  support  the  Planning 
Commission.  The  functions  and  facilities  of  the  National  Energy  Conservation  Centre  will  be 
realigned  into  the  Planning  Commission.  Stakeholder  consultations  will  be  done  at  the 
Government’s EECCG.  
 
132.  A  risk  management  framework  will  be  prepared  for  each  project.  Projects  will  be 
subjected to project readiness filters. Simple project designs will be conscientiously applied, and 
active due diligence will help avoid quality gaps and start-up delays. Contracts will be bundled 
into large packages. ADB will monitor the program through the Pakistan Resident Mission, with 
support from the energy team at ADB headquarters. 
 
133.  The  CFL  project  has  some  risks:  (i)  timely  procurement  of  CFLs  and  their  distribution 
without  any  leakage  to  the  commercial  market;  (ii)  capacity  of  DISCOs  to  undertake  timely 
distribution of  CFLs,  and  (iii)  the  Government’s  ability  to  implement  and  enforce  strict  controls 
on energy-efficiency testing and labeling of CFLs.  
 
134.  These risks will be mitigated by ensuring (i) the use of international energy performance 
standards  and  international  competitive  bidding  for  the  bulk  procurement  of  CFLs;  (ii)  that 
distribution of CFLs to customers is done at customer homes; (iii) that each CFL will be clearly 
marked “not for sale;” and (iv) that suppliers deliver the CFLs directly to the DISCO distribution 
points. Customers will receive voucher(s) as part of their electricity bill and be made aware of 
the free distribution via saturation media communication and social mobilization campaign.  
 
135.  Appropriate  monitoring  mechanisms  for  effective  distribution  and  reporting  of  the  CFL 
logistics  and  transactions  will  be  developed.  All  relevant  stakeholders  will  be  invited  to 
participate  in  developing  the  proposed  CFL  and  voucher  distribution  mechanism.  The 
mechanism  will  be  optimized  during  implementation  of  the  first  procurement  and  distribution 
phase.  Lessons  from  the  distribution  of  the  first  phase  will  be  incorporated  in  the  subsequent 
phase.

NATIONAL COMPACT FLUORESCENT LAMP PROJECT 
 

1. 
The  initial  tranche  of  the  Energy  Efficiency  Investment  Program  will  involve  the 
replacement  of  incandescent  bulbs  in  30  million  residential  light  points  with  long-life,  high-
efficiency compact fluorescent lamps (CFLs) within the license areas of nine distribution utilities 
in Pakistan. The Government of Pakistan is sponsoring this project. It will be implemented jointly 
by the eight power distribution companies (DISCOs) and the Karachi Electric Supply Company 
(KESC)  over  28  months  with  two  procurement  and  distribution  phases.  The  $85  million  CFL 
project  will  reduce  peak  demand  by  1,094  megawatts  (MW);  avoid  1,602  MW  in  generating 
capacity  additions,  corresponding  to  $1.84  billion  in  new  generation  investments;  save 
$800 million in household electricity expenses; result in 2,132 gigawatt-hours (GWh) of annual 
electricity consumption reductions; avoid 7 million tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions by the 
end of 2018, and accelerate the transformation of the incandescent bulb market to high-quality 
CFLs.  The  $25  million  Investment  Program  Management  Support  Project  will  enable 
incandescent bulb phaseout, as well as build institutional capacities for the adoption of energy 
performance standards, testing of CFLs and other appliances, and lamp waste management. 

Background 

A.  
 
2. 
Since 2006, electricity demand in Pakistan has greatly outstripped available generation 
capacity. The resulting load shedding and power outages caused street protests in many cities 
in  early  2009.  Businesses  have  gone  on  strike  to  protest  the  worsening  electricity  supply 
problem. In July 2009 the country faced power shortages of approximately 5,000 MW. Demand 
is  expected  to  exceed  supply  by  more  than  5,500  MW  in  2010.  The  present  electricity  supply 
shortfall, coupled with consistent growth in demand (7%–8% per annum), clearly indicates the 
critical need for enhancing the country’s current power generation capability as well as curtailing 
unnecessary consumption.

Peak  Demand  Reduction  and  Avoided  Peak  Generation  Capacities.  Average  daily 
and hourly electricity demand in Pakistan varies by season. Lighting demand is affected by the

lighting  load  is  higher  than  in  summer  months.  Mainly  due  to  lighting  load,  the  National 
Transmission  and  Despatch  Company’s  system  peak  starts  at  around  8:00  p.m.  during

To assess the impact of CFL replacement, data for two peak months was analyzed, with 
August  representing  the  summer  season  and  January  representing  winter.  The  average  daily

peak  demand  over  the  daily  base  demand  is  projected  to  be  2,468  MW  during  summer  and 
2,027 MW during winter in FY2010, mainly contributed to by lighting loads. The projected peak 
demand rise for FY2011 is 2,662 MW for the summer and 2,178 MW for the winter. 

14. 
The domestic sector connected  to the grid is estimated to have about 41.78  million light 
points presently fitted with incandescent bulbs. Under this project, 10 million incandescent bulbs in 
the 40–100 W range will be replaced in 2010 (phase 1) and another 20 million in 2011 (phase 2).

replacement of 30 million incandescent bulbs with CFLs, having average consumption of 21.5 W 
per lamp, will result in an estimated reduction of peak demand by about 1,094 MW (at 66% peak 
coincidence). The peak demand reduction is estimated to be 365 MW for phase 1 and 729 MW 
for phase 2. This translates into a 53.9% peak demand reduction from the total incandescent bulb 
load of 2,028 MW after phase 2. Considering upstream losses and reserve margin requirements, 
the project is capable of avoiding $1.84 billion in investments for 1,602 MW in new installed peak 
generation capacities. Figure A4.2 shows the impact of the CFL replacement project on the daily

CFL  Waste  Management  Facility.  Burnt-out  CFLs  are  potentially  hazardous  waste 
11. 
because  of  the  presence  of  mercury.  Disposal  into  municipal  landfill  and  dumping  sites  can 
result in release of mercury into the soil and to water bodies. Currently, the country has no lamp 
waste management facility. The waste generated from fluorescent tube lights (FTLs) and CFLs 
used in the country are dumped with other municipal waste into various waste dumping sites or 
are  crushed  without  any  safety  consideration  for  disposal  of  glass.  The  30  million  CFLs  to  be 
distributed under the proposed program will contain between 100 and 120 kilograms of mercury. 
Thus a lamp waste management facility (LWMF) with the required handling capacity is needed. 
Modern facilities are designed to recover glass, metal, mercury, and chloride salt from the waste 
lamp for reuse.   
 
12. 
The  proposed  CFL  distribution  program  envisages  distribution  of  10  million  CFLs  in 
phase 1, spread over 4 months, and distribution of another 20 million CFLs in phase 2, spread 
over 6 months. Phase 2 will be initiated about 8 months after completion of phase 1. The CFLs 
procured for distribution will have a specified life of 10,000 hours. Given that the average usage 
of CFLs in the domestic sector is about 3.5 hours per day, the CFLs are expected to last more 
than 8 years, on average. However, issues with waste CFLs are likely to start much before that 
for a number of reasons. First, manufacturing defects and mishandling may result in burning out 
and  breakage  of  CFLs  before  completion  of  their  rated  life.  Second,  the  CFLs  may  replace 
FTLs,  which  also  contain  about  10–15  milligrams  of  mercury  and  require  a  proper  handling 
facility. Third, the awareness campaign associated with the program is likely to generate a need 
for a waste disposal facility for the CFLs already in use in the country. About 3% of the CFLs 
(900,000) distributed under the program are expected to require disposal within 3 years after the 
start  of  the  program.  As  the  typical  capacity  of  a  compact  lamp  waste  management  facility  is 
about  0.4  million–0.5  million  CFLs  per  month,  the  program  envisages  that  a  facility  will  be 
developed and begin operating in year 3 of the program.  
 
13. 
To  make  the  facility  a  viable  and  sustainable  mechanism,  waste  treatment  will  be 
organized on a commercial basis. Payment will be made for used CFLs and for fluorescents in 
general.  One  option  is  to  get  trash  collectors  to  pick  up  used  fluorescents,  bring  them  to  a 
collection  point,  and  be  paid  for  the  waste.  Private  trash  recyclers  could  manage  and  run  the 
central waste collection facilities suitably located around the country.  
 
14. 
Once  lamps  have  been  accumulated  at  the  collection  points,  a  recycling  mechanism 
would need to be set up to treat them. The CFL project will provide an opportunity to establish 
required recycling facilities in the country for all fluorescent lamps. Survey results show that the 
domestic sector in Pakistan currently has 113 million light points. Of these, approximately 60% 
utilize  fluorescent  lamps,  including  tubes  and  existing  CFLs.  Up  to  four  recycling  facilities  are 
expected to be required initially, perhaps distributed across the capitals of each province to limit, 
as much as possible, the cost of transportation of used fluorescent lamps.

2.

incandescent bulbs in the domestic sector with efficient, high-quality compact fluorescent lamps

1,094 megawatt reduction in peak evening electricity demand, resulting in savings in electricity

harmful  impact  of  mercury  on  human  health  is  caused  by  long-term,  low,  or  chronic  exposure,

Pakistan is currently faced with a serious energy crisis to which inefficient use of available 
energy resources is identified as one of the key contributors. The economic and social impacts of

conditions  of  workers.  Its  social  benefits  will  reduce  the  adverse  impact  of  power  outages  on 
social life, education, and quality of life in general. Indirect and wider economic benefits can also 
follow to the community through, for example, increased business opportunities for local suppliers 
and retailers.

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

 

A.   Links to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Despite  recent  efforts  to  increase  capacity  and  supply,  Pakistan  is  presently  suffering  from  a  serious  energy 
shortfall.  The  shortfall  is  more  pronounced  in  the  electricity  subsector  during  peak  hours  resulting  in  significant 
power  cuts  affecting  economic  activity  and  delivery  of  social  services.  Recently  these  resulted  in  reduced 
production  in  various  industries  that  left  many  workers,  mostly  belonging  to  the  poor  segments  of  society, 
unemployed. In addition, the phased adjustment of petroleum prices and electricity tariffs starting in 2008 following 
the increase in international oil prices burdened poor consumers with increased expenses in meeting their energy 
needs. 

Achieving energy security and energy affordability are two main goals set in the Vision 2030 and the Medium-Term 
Development Framework of Pakistan. The recently updated Poverty Reduction Strategy (PRSP-II) for 2009–2011 
aims at achieving poverty reduction through sustainable economic growth and employment generation. In achieving 
these objectives the strategy regards the following as essential: the provision of adequate energy (i) to industry to 
drive  economic  growth  and  create  employment  opportunities,  (ii)  to  the  domestic  sector  for  cooking  and  heating, 
and  (iii)  to  prevent  the  continuing  environmental  degradation  and  deforestation  by  massive  use  of  wood  for 
domestic fuel. Based on these government priorities, improving energy efficiency is among the key target outcomes 
of  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  sector  assistance  under  its  country  partnership  strategy  (2009–2013)  for 
Pakistan.a 

The energy savings resulting from improved efficiency under the proposed program are expected to provide a more 
reliable energy supply to various sectors of the economy. The resulting sustained economic activity in particular in 
the industry sector will indirectly benefit industrial laborers as their jobs will no longer be threatened by power cuts. 
Poor and vulnerable consumers, including social utilities like hospitals and schools, often hardest hit by insufficient 
power  supply  and  load  shedding  will  also  benefit  from  efficient  and  more  reliable  delivery  of  services.  Under  the 
compact  fluorescent  lamp  (CFL)  distribution  program,  the  use  of  CFLs  by  low-income  (lifeline  tariff)  customers 
expressed as a percentage of total lighting points used is expected to increase from the current 34% of households 
to 74% of households after two phases of distribution. 

B.  Poverty Analysis                                Targeting Classification: General intervention 
1.   Key Issues  
 
Efficient energy use in all sectors of the economy is expected to help reduce the overall rate of increase of energy 
demand  to  more  manageable  levels  and  reduce  potential  shortages.  Energy  efficiency  can  reduce  large  financial 
outlays  required  for  developing  additional  energy  supplies  in  the  future.  It  can  also  help  minimize  uneconomical 
standby  capacity  required  to  cater  to  peak  loads,  reduce  subsidy  requirements,  and  defer  transmission  system 
expansion  needs,  thereby  saving  public  funds  and  increasing  returns  on  energy  infrastructure  investments  that 
could, in return, be directed to social programs. 

Poor  sectors  of  society  are  more  often  among  the  hardest  hit  by  the  shortfall  in  energy  supply.  Typically  the 
duration  of  load  shedding  is  far  higher  in  rural  areas  than  in  urban  areas  or  relatively  larger  cities.  The  poor  are 
expected  to  benefit  from  energy  savings  realized  from  implementation  of  energy  efficiency  interventions  with 
reliable access to energy and improved lighting. This would have an improved impact on households’ economic and 
social activities in the evening. In addition, the communication and social mobilization component will provide poor 
households with information on other affordable energy efficient choices to reduce household energy expenditure. 
The impact of the promotion of CFLs also depends on affordability and effective distribution channels.
